entry.title: *** New Get Certified series covering all areas in the C_S4CFI certification.** Register now
entry.content:
Overview

In this Get Certified series, expert trainers will deliver knowledge transfer sessions covering all areas in the C_S4CFI certification.

Learners who attend the series will receive expert-guided support to complement their self-study activities. Through the live sessions, they will be part of a group where summaries of course content are presented, complicated topics are repeated, and questions can be clarified.

To prepare for the exam, you should first work through all courses in the learning journey Implementing Financial Accounting in SAP S/4HANA Cloud. In addition, you should join the live sessions. Your trainer will review the content and focus on the most important topics relevant to the exam, to give you the best chance of success.

The following content will be covered:

  • Session 1: Kick Off: Outlining the series, introducing the certification, explaining the question types, tips for preparation, sample questions in the exam interface
  • Session 2: Implementing SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Unit 1 - 7
  • Session 3: Implementing SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Unit 8 - 12
  • Session 4: Detailing Accruals Management & Detailing Financial Statement Reporting
  • Session 5: Detailing Configuration of R2R Posting Processes
  • Session 6: Detailing Settings for Asset Accounting, Detailing Asset Accounting Integration Aspects & Detailing Asset Accounting Year-End Closing Activities
  • Session 7: Detailing Down Payments Execution , Detailing the Configuration for the Payment Run & Detailing Process Automation in Accounts Payable
  • Session 8: Detailing Special G/L Transactions in Accounts Receivable & Detailing SAP Cash Application and Processing Rules for Bank Statements
  • Session 9: Detailing Dispute and Collections Management & Detailing Credit Management Processes in Accounts Receivable
  • Session 10: Detailing the Dunning Run and closing wrap-up before the exam

Learning objectives

After participating in this Get Certified live session series, you will understand the format, scope and be ready to attempt the certification C_S4CFI

entry.title: Re: SAP Public cloud Sourcing and Procurement- Monitor Pu...
entry.content:
Hi @Rushabh1810 

A very good morning to you too.

Thank you for the confirmation. You’ve done everything expected up to this point.

Only item-level down payments on approved Purchase Orders are visible in that app See KBA 3071689 for more details. If your PO is still in a 'To Be Approved' or “draft” state, or the down payment is defined only at the header but not the item, the app won’t show it. See SAP Support Portal for further details.

My suggestion is to check:

  • Confirm your PO has been approved/released.
  • Confirm you defined the down payment at the item-level, not just the header.

Once those conditions are met, the app should appear in your Launchpad and show your PO.

Best regards,

Chris

entry.title: Partner function not available in Manage Purchase Order app
entry.content:
In the Manage Purchase Order application, the Partner function or Partner tab is missing when creating a new purchase order or when viewing existing purchase orders associated with Partner roles.
This issue is not observed in the Purchase Order Advanced app (ME2xN), where the Partner function is visible. However, the Partner function remains unavailable in other purchase order applications.

The absence of the Partner function in the Manage Purchase Orders app is due to it not being enabled in the system configurations.

This function can be activated through the IMG, following the specified path for both SAP S/4 HANA On-Premise and SAP S/4 HANA Cloud Private Edition.
Path --> SAP Customising Implementation Guide -> Materials Management -> Purchasing -> Environment Data -> Enable Partner Functions in Manage Purchase Orders Application.

If It's SAP S/4 HANA Cloud Public Edition, use SSCUI - 106258 – Enable Partner Functions in Manage Purchase Orders (PO) Application.

Important Note: Once the switch state is changed to ON, it cannot be set to OFF again. 

After activating the above-given configuration Partner tab will appear in the "Manage Purchase Order" app.

 

Thanks 
Santosh G
SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition Sourcing and Procurement SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Sourcing and Procurement

entry.title: Re: No materials were selected for the costing run CK078...
entry.content:
In which version, you are working. There is one SAP note 587881 for this issue CK078 but it is for lower version.

Now coming to your issue, not sure, whether you run ck40n with new a New Costing Run name. If not, once again, run ck40n with new a New Costing Run name and check for the below parameters.

As you would know, CK40N uses quantity structure determination, which requires active BOM for the material, Valid routing or recipe and Validity dates that match the costing date. CK11N can bypass some of these checks, but CK40N is stricter. So while running ck40n again with new name, ensure the following: -

After creating the costing run, go to Costing Level Overview. Make sure the costing levels are selected and saved before running structure explosion. If no costing level is flagged, CK40N won’t pick up any materials, even if they’re valid.

Also, test with the below parameters

  • Only one material
  • Costing level manually selected
  • BOM and routing confirmed as active
  • Validity date aligned with costing date

If it still fails, try enabling log output to see where the selection fails.

entry.title: Re: Lease contract condition
entry.content:
Try the below approach which I am not sure whether it will work

Go to RECN (Real Estate Contract Management). Select your lease contract and create a change version. Set the change date to sometime in 2025 (e.g., 01.01.2025).

In the change version, go to the Conditions tab,  locate the condition for the period 3.04.2024 – 2.04.2027,  reduce the amount to 90,000 and set the new validity date to reflect only 2025.

You may need to split the condition so that:

  • 3.04.2024 – 31.12.2024 = 0
  • 01.01.2025 – 31.12.2025 = 90,000

If the original 270,000 was already posted, you’ll need to reverse the excess payments using transaction F-02 or FB08 Or post an adjustment entry to reflect the revised payment schedule.

In the same change version, go to the Contract Term tab. Set the new end date to 31.12.2025 (or your desired termination date). This ensures no future conditions or valuations are generated beyond 2025.

Run the valuation again using RECNVAL or mass valuation. This will update the lease liability and right-of-use asset based on the new payment and shortened term

entry.title: Re: Unable to Clear Special G/L Transactions with CME Ind...
entry.content:
Hi @Blas4 

Thanks for the visuals and your precise question.

  • you cannot replace or customize the Special G/L indicator “S” In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition. This is fixed by SAP, as described in KBA 2761212.
  • You can, however, adjust the reconciliation account for indicator “S” through the Automatic Account Determination configuration (SSCUI 100297), but this does not affect clearing behaviour.
  • Manual clearing of items with indicator “S” is only supported if they were posted via a down‑payment request. Then they can be cleared using the “Post to G/L Account” tab in the Clear Incoming Payments app. Simply changing payment method or customizing the indicator will not enable manual clearing in standard apps.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: CAP + SAPUI5 - How does auth work?
entry.content:
Hi again,

after having extensively tried and researched on this topic it seems to me that there is no other way than having an authenticated user with the respective roles to trigger an action (POST Request) from a deployed SAPUI5 app. 

Which is why I have been trying to set up XSUAA token-based auth. However, I can't seem to make it work. The setup of the CAP backend should be alright, as I have already tested and verified that it works the way it should via POSTMAN (Got the token, triggered the endpoints, etc...)

Nonetheless, it does not work from the SAPUI5 Apps.  As soon as I change the destination pointing to the CAP backend to OAuth2ClientCredentials/OAuth2UserTokenExchange the apps won't start at all - 500 - or they do start but still hit a 401 OR 500 error (On every request - even get). The credentials (Clientid/secret) are 100% correct.

What I did regarding the frontend:

- Setup the destination with the respective OAuth2 credentials from the xsuaa service instance

- Setup the xs-app.json: 

{
  "welcomeFile": "/index.html",
  "authenticationMethod": "route",
  "routes": [
    {
      "source": "^/odata/(.*)$",
      "target": "/odata/$1",
      "destination": "THE DESTINATION I CONFIGURED",
      "authenticationType": "xsuaa"

    {
      "source": "^/resources/(.*)$",
      "target": "/resources/$1",
      "authenticationType": "none",
      "destination": "ui5"

    {
      "source": "^/test-resources/(.*)$",
      "target": "/test-resources/$1",
      "authenticationType": "none",
      "destination": "ui5"

      "target": "$1",

  ]
}

Also what I find odd is that when I setup the destination and try to create a new SAPUI5 App from template and choose the destination even there it returns 500.
 
What am I missing?

entry.title: How Joule Enhances Employee Experience in SAP SuccessFactors Enterprise Service Management
entry.content:
Employees today expect quick, intuitive, and personalized support—especially when navigating important life events like parental leave. SAP SuccessFactors Enterprise Service Management delivers on that expectation, with Joule, SAP’s AI copilot, at the heart of the experience.

AI-Powered Self-Sufficiency for Employees

Joule plays a critical role in making employees more self-sufficient by providing instant, conversational access to information and HR services. Whether they need to understand policies, complete tasks, or access resources, Joule guides them to the right answers and actions—without navigating complex portals or waiting on HR teams.

Key benefits for employees include:

  • Instant, personalized responses to HR questions
  • Guided access to relevant self-service actions, such as submitting requests or finding forms
  • A conversational, intuitive experience, available across devices

With Joule embedded in SAP SuccessFactors Enterprise Service Management, employees get the support they need, when they need it—within the flow of work.

Consider an employee, Alex, who is preparing for the arrival of a new baby and needs information about parental leave. Instead of searching through policies or submitting a ticket, Alex interacts with Joule.

Here’s how Joule enhances the experience:

Alex opens SAP SuccessFactors Work Zone and types:
“What do I need to do to apply for parental leave?”

Joule instantly responds:
“Congratulations! I can help you with that. Here's the parental leave policy and a step-by-step guide to apply. Would you like to start the process now?”

Alex selects 'Yes,' and Joule provides a link to the self-service form, pre-populated with relevant information.

If Alex has further questions—such as eligibility or pay details—Joule provides immediate answers or directs them to the appropriate resources.

Only if Alex faces a complex issue or needs additional support, Joule helps create a service request, capturing the conversation's context to streamline the process.

Minimizing Case Creation, Maximizing Experience

This example reflects the broader goal of modern HR service delivery: empowering employees to resolve everyday needs quickly while reducing unnecessary case creation.

Joule enables this by:

  • Deflecting cases through real-time answers and guided self-service
  • Providing easy access to policies, forms, and next steps
  • Only triggering case creation when personal assistance is truly needed

When a case is required, Joule captures the context and helps craft the request—saving time for both employees and HR teams.

A Smarter Way to Deliver HR Support

Joule is more than a chatbot—it’s an integral part of SAP’s vision for AI-driven HR service delivery. By combining intelligent self-service, conversational guidance, and smart case initiation, Joule enhances the overall employee experience while driving efficiency for HR teams.

In short: Joule makes it easier for employees to navigate important moments—like parental leave—quickly, confidently, and on their own terms.

Stay tuned for our next blog, where we will explore how generative AI within SAP SuccessFactors Enterprise Service Management is transforming the agent experience behind the scenes.

 For more solution info, please visit the SAP SuccessFactors Enterprise Service Management website.

entry.title: Re: GetDefaultsForItem issue
Best practice test cases for S/4 HANA processes in Cloud ALM
entry.content:
Prerequisites

We'll assume you have set up a Cloud ALM implementation project.
We will further assume you have already selected the process scope (chosen the S/4 standard processes you are looking to implement):


Cloud ALM End-to-End Implementation Process

With there prerequisites met,  we can already navigate to the processes and start downloading test cases.

 

Downloading a best practice test case

Open the Processes App in Cloud ALM and open a solution process.

With  tab "Solution Value flow" open on the left hand side, go to tab "Process Hierarchy Nodes" on the right hand side.
Scroll down to the "Accelerators" section and click the Link "Test script (SAP Cloud ALM)".
This will download an excel version of the best practice test case.

This Excel representation of the test case could be uploaded as a test case to cloud ALM right away, but the more likely scenario is that it will be adjusted first to make it fit your project / team / test data situation.
The best practice test cases are *very* detailed and cover a lot of additional information and preparational steps such as creating the necessary master data first. The "Accounting and Financial Close (J58)" case for example had 370 lines.

Note: Not all solution processes/country versions have a "Test script (SAP Cloud ALM)" available yet.
Some will just have a "Test script" (same content but in Word format rather than Excel).

 

Test case structure & editing in excel

The structure of a test case in Cloud ALM (and thus in the excel representation as well) is as follows:

  • Test Case
    • Activity 
      • Action
        • Action Title
        • Action Instructions
        • Action Expected Result 

The texts in the excel cells come HTML formatted. While not visible in Excel, the formating will be applied when the case is displayed in Cloud ALM.
Note: There are more columns in the excel, which have been hidden for this example to focus on what's relevant.

Once the test case has been adjusted in excel, save the excel and  upload the adjusted test case to Cloud ALM. 


Uploading the test case to Cloud ALM

Open Cloud ALM's  "Test preparation" app and click the "Upload test tase" button.
Chose the excel file, containing the previously adjusted test case, select a scope and start the upload. 

If everything works well, you will se the message "The item in your uploaded file will be created." and the new test case will appear in the "Test Peparation" app.

In case the upload of the test case fails, there will be (unless the structure is completely broken) a detailed error message, pointing you to the problem in the excel file:

In this example two Action Instructions were missing.

Once you click on the test case, you can make further adjustments in Cloud ALM.
You will recognize the already familiar structure:

The hierarchical numbering (i.e. "6.1") is automatically added by Cloud ALM.

 

Next Steps 

What happens next?
Typically the test case is (once reviewed/signed off) switched to status "Prepared", which makes it available for test execution.
The test case can now be added to a test plan ("Test Plans" app), where a tester can be assigned  and then test execution/documentation can begin with the "Test execution" app.

 

Summary / closing thoughts

Best practice test cases now being readily available in CLoud ALM uploadable excel format is a major convenience gain.
More Cloud ALM features/improvements are being rolled out on a bi-weekly schedule. You can stay up-to-date with the links below:
Which Cloud ALM features have been added recently? LINK
Which Cloud ALM features are in the pipeline? LINK
Want to try Cloud ALM for yourself? Try the Public Demo System.

entry.title: Re: SAP Public cloud Sourcing and Procurement- Monitor Pu...
entry.content:
Hi Rush

Thanks for confirming all your settings and sharing the screenshots. This helps pinpoint the issue precisely.

You mentioned you created this PO via SAP GUI, not through the Fiori app, which leads to the core issue. Please note that GUI-created POs are not supported for visibility in Fiori down payment monitoring. The Monitor Purchase Order Down Payments app only recognizes down payments created via the Fiori process, using: “Create Purchase Order Advanced” then followed by “Manage Supplier Down Payment Requests”.

Note that POs created manually via SAP GUI are not captured by the Monitor app and therefore never appear in F2877. 

Even though you've verified that the PO is approved and the down payment is defined at item level, the Monitor Purchase Order Down Payments (F2877) app intentionally does not support POs created using SAP GUI. It only tracks POs built via the Fiori "Create Purchase Order Advanced" app followed by the standard down payment request flow. To resolve this, I recommend the following:

  • Recreate your PO via the Fiori app instead of SAP GUI.
  • Assign the Mandatory Down Payment at the item level.
  • Go through Monitor Purchase Order Down Payments, then “Create Down Payment Request” and finally “Manage Supplier Down Payment Requests”.

Once the PO is built in the Fiori flow, it will show up for monitoring. This is fully documented and the only SAP‑supported way in Public Cloud.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Sales Document Approval – Standard Workflow : Re-Approval

Thanks for any advice.

Dan

entry.title: Anna Hartmann
entry.content:
Anna

  • Germany
  • SAP Mentor since 2025
  • Follow Anna on LinkedIn

Anna is managing director at in4MD Service GmbH. Her journey began with mastering ABAP programming from 2010 to 2013. By 2013, Anna was deeply involved in the HANA environment, managing around 100 databases and developing teaching materials covering areas such as Predictive Analysis Library, Geospatial, Text Mining, Fiori development on HANA, and Smart Data Integration for the SAP University Alliance Program in the SAP University Competence Center Magdeburg. This extensive engagement has equipped her with an in-depth knowledge of the entire HANA platform, both 1.0 and 2.0. Anna is also one of the authors of the SAP Press book "SAP HANA – Datenbankadministration" (ISBN 978-3-8362-6850-9).

Topics of interest: HANA database, HANA Cloud, SAP landscape and architecture, ABAP, BTP

Marla, what inspired you to become an SAP Mentor?

What drives Anna is ensuring the needs of mid-sized customers are met, as they often feel overlooked by SAP. Anna is passionate about being their voice, representing their interests whether through on-premise solutions, cloud (Azure, Google), or RISE and GROW projects. Her diverse background and commitment to these clients makes her an ideal candidate for the SAP Mentor Program, where I can advocate effectively for this crucial segment of the SAP community. Anna also has a broad network within the technical SAP community thanks to the many years of involvement in DSAG.

What advice would like to share with other SAP community members?

Get involved into the SAP community, it's a great opportunity to learn from others and gain different perspectives. Stay curious and continuously learn about new SAP technologies and best practices. Network actively with other SAP professionals to share insights and solve challenges together. Always keep the core business processes of your company or customer in mind to deliver real value with your technical solutions.

entry.title: Absolute Tax Exchange Rate in C/R Currency in S/4HANA Public Cloud
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community,

We have encountered an issue during the posting of multiple supplier and customer invoices where the tax reporting country is set to NL (a valid and active RITA country). Despite the configuration of exchange rate type "M" as the standard, the system is not using it to calculate the exchange rate. Instead, the system appears to be deriving the exchange rate from an "Absolute Tax Exchange Rate in C/R Currency," for which no values are maintained. This behavior seems inconsistent with expected standard processing and may indicate a gap in the standard functionality or underlying logic.

Regards,

Kunal Gupta

entry.title: Re: Sales Document Approval – Standard Workflow : Re-Appr...
entry.content:
Hi Dan

You can achieve your approval goal using standard Public Cloud BAdI logic.

Here is my recommendation:

  • Use the SD_APM_SET_APPROVAL_REASON BADI to check what fields were changed.
  • Have it set an approval reason only if critical fields, for example price or quantity changed.
  • If the non-critical fields are changed, leave the approval reason blank. This avoids resetting the Approval Status and keeps the document in “Released” status.

One important thing: make sure your approval workflow conditions match the reasons you set in the BADI. If you set a reason that doesn’t match any workflow start condition, the document will get stuck in “In Approval” without going to anyone.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: "Type of Impact" column is blank in SAP Readiness Che...
entry.content:
The "Type of Impact" column is empty, as no IDocs were reported as impacted based on the scope of the analysis.

We still advise testing business-critical interfaces as part of their validation, as not all types of change are assessed by integration analysis. More specifically, SAP Readiness Check looks for IDocs that were deleted, blocked, or have known serialization issues.

Other changes, like correction instructions delivered as part of an SAP Note bound into a software component update, for example - are not assessed.

For more details on Impact Analysis and Impact Types within Integration Analysis, please see the following SAP Community Blog: https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/extended-integration-analysis-in-sap-readiness-check-impact-analysis-in/ba-p/13503346

Kind regards,
SAP Support

entry.title: Multiple currencies in bank statement
entry.content:
Hello all,

We have a scenario where a local INR-denominated bank account supports foreign currency receipts/payments. Any foreign currency is automatically converted by the bank and debited/credited accordingly from the account in INR.

However, in SAP during bank statement processing (e.g., clearing AP open items in foreign currency), we encounter an error: "Transaction currency differs from the house bank currency." As per SAP Note 3115215, the transaction and house bank currencies must match for posting.

Since banks do not issue separate statements per currency, and splitting statements by currency affects opening/closing balances (requiring manual adjustments), is there a recommended best practice or workaround to handle such cases efficiently in the 'Manage Bank Statements' app?

Thank you.

Best regards,

Rishav.

Hi @rosa-limardo 

there is an accelerator (Excel File) Configuration Activity which you can download. It is basically a list of all configuration activities you can perform in CBC (based on the activated countries and scope items)

In the second tab, you will find a list with the connection of Scope Item ID (SSCUI ID), Application (IAM App ID) and required Business Catalog.

Regarding your example: You can filter in column Transaction Code or IAM App ID for S_ER9_11001473. In column A you will find the required catalog to perform this configuration activity. (SAP_CA_BC_IC_LND_FIN_WT_ES_PC)

Now you need to check if the mentioned catalog (SAP_CA_BC_IC_LND_FIN_WT_ES_PC) is assigned to your configuration business role. (If you are using copies of the SAP Template Roles, if would be the SAP_BR_BPC_EXPERT) If the catalog is not yet included, you need to assign it. Additionally this configuration role needs to be assigned to the user who wants to perform the configuration.

If you need further assistance, let me know.

Kind regards,

Melanie

entry.title: Navigating SAF-T in Portugal: The Crucial Difference Between E-fatura and Audit Files
entry.content:
Hello all,

A common point of confusion is the difference between the SAF-T file used for “e-fatura reporting” and the comprehensive file required for a “tax audit”. Understanding this distinction is not just a matter of compliance; it’s about making your monthly tasks simpler and more efficient.

Let's break down the two uses and what you need to know.

What is SAF-T (PT)? A Quick Refresher

At its core, the SAF-T PT is a predefined XML file that contains a company's essential master data, accounting, billing, and tax data in a standardized format. This allows the Portuguese Tax Authority (AT) to easily process and validate information from thousands of different businesses using different software systems.

The Monthly Task: SAF-T for E-fatura Reporting

This is the SAF-T file that most businesses generate every month (although you can extract it for smaller periods). Its sole purpose is to communicate all fiscally relevant billing documents issued during that period to the AT's e-fatura portal.

The focus here is strictly on billing. This file must contain:

Sales Invoices

  • Invoices
  • Debit notes
  • Credit notes

Working Documents

  • Pro-forma documents

Payments

  • Receipts from payment documents

Crucially, the standard monthly e-fatura SAF-T file does not require information about the movement of goods. This means documents like shipping notes are excluded.

The goal is efficiency. By submitting only the necessary billing data, the file is smaller, generates faster, and the validation process on the e-fatura portal is streamlined.

The Deep Dive: SAF-T for Audit Purposes

This is the "full-scope" SAF-T file. You don't submit this monthly; instead, you generate it only when the Tax Authority formally requests it during an inspection or audit. This file is designed to give the AT a complete, detailed picture of your company's operations. You can also create it as part of your year end tasks.

What’s Included?

Accounting documents

Sales Invoices

  • Invoices
  • Debit notes
  • Credit notes

Movement of goods

  • Delivery documents

Working Documents

  • Pro-forma documents

Payments

  • Receipts from payment documents

Making Compliance Simple

Manually adding or removing sections from an XML file is not feasible and prone to error. That’s why modern billing software is designed to handle this distinction automatically.

Our solution acknowledges these different requirements by providing you with the flexibility to choose the type of SAF-T file you need to generate. When running the extraction, you can select which type of file you need to extract.

For more information:

SAF-T in Public Cloud Edition 

SAF-T in S4HANA

SAF-T in ERP

entry.title: Credit Management Functionalities in S4 Service Management
entry.content:
How Credit Management is used in S4HANA Service? How is this different from Traditional ECC?

  • In ECC the Credit exposure of Customer is Monitored at Credit Control Area level, but in S4HANA Credit Exposure is Monitored at Credit Segment level, which is assigned to Business Partner.
  • In S/4 HANA, the Credit Management Master Data is maintained in Business Partner Level. For this, we need to extend a new role (UKM000) as Credit Management under the relevant BP.
  • Once you extend the credit management role, you can see there are two parts activated for Credit Management (Credit Profile and Credit Segment Data). We maintain all the Credit Management related data within these two sections.

Transaction : BP

2. Enterprise Structure of SAP S4HANA Credit Management for Service Management Scenario:                        

  • Credit segments are required for calculating the credit limit and enable user to carry out detailed checks at Business Partner level. When you define a credit segment, you also decide the currency in which all credit-relevant checks are to be carried out. For standard currency conversion user can verify Transaction: OB08 or Table: TCURR

    Application Example of Credit Segment:

    You have a customer with subsidiaries in different countries. You can create a separate credit segment for each country so that you can assign different credit limits to the different subsidiaries. If you want to assign one credit limit for all countries in which a customer has subsidiaries, you have to Map credit segment 0000.
  • Credit Control Area is an organizational unit that specifies and checks a credit limit for customers.
  • Multiple CCA can assign to One Credit Segment
  • Credit Limit is defined at Credit Segment Level in the Credit Segment data Tab in BP
  • After assigning/updating Credit Limit there is a workflow approval process and the authorized person approve the Credit limit assigned.

Credit Limit Assignment: Users can define the Credit Limit 1) By Updating the Limit at BP level with request Approval from Approvers 2) Using Credit Rules

Credit rules are defined in the system in order to calculate the Credit limit and the Score. In the configuration path below you can create the rules to calculate credit limit and score with user defined formulas.
Score is calculated by the system based on the formula defined in the above configuration path. The calculated score can be overwritten with manually entered values.

Risk Classes: Users can create risk classes in the below configuration path. 
Financial Supply Chain Management -> Credit Risk Monitoring -> Master Data -> Create Risk Classes
We can assign the score ranges to each risk class, once the score is calculated by the system, the risk class will be picked automatically in the master data. Risk Classes are mapped under Rating procedures, under Define Rating procedures in Configuration. 
Rating procedures are assigned under Business Partner --> Under Credit Profile section, Under External Credit Information and the Risk classes are derived from Rating procedures based on Customer Credit profiles score.

Note: Rules, Score and Credit Group are used for Automatic calculation of credit limit by the system which is set based on calculation define after interface with Credit rating agencies like Standard & Poor, Moody's D&B 

Integration to External Credit Agencies can be done under below path:
Financial Supply Chain Management -> Credit Risk Monitoring -> Master Data -> Integration of  External Credit Agencies

Configurations Specific to S4HANA Service Management: 
1.  Activate/Deactivate Credit Management: User can Activate or deactivate SAP Credit Management by selecting the check box
2. Define Credit Segments
3. Assign Credit Control Area to Credit Segments
4. Assign Sales Area to Credit Control Areas 
5. Activate Credit Management in Service Transactions    
6. Activate credit check at Items.

Once Credit checks are active in system, User should assign the SAP_BR_CREDIT_CONTROLLER Business Role and Activate event (CL_UKM_DCD_WF_EVENT) to view blocked transactions (Service Orders, Contracts) due to credit limit Exposure under “Documented credit Decisions” FIORI App.

Thank you,
Azad M

entry.title: Convert Key User Custom Fields to ABAP Managed Fields (AMF)
entry.content:
Introduction

Have you ever been in the situation that you created a key user custom field and then, when wanting to change the metadata of the field, the change turned out to be only supported by ABAP Managed Fields? 

If your answer is yes, then this blog post is just for you. In this blog, you'll learn how to convert a “normal” key user custom field to an ABAP Managed Field. With that, you can do all the changes supported by ABAP Managed Fields.

You can refer to this blog for an introduction into ABAP Managed Fields.

Let's say that you created a key user custom field of type “Code List”. You want to change the code list values directly in the production system instead of maintaining them in the development system and then transporting them over to the production system. You can refer to this blog for a comprehensive overview of custom field types providing a value list.
There may also be other reasons why you want to transform a key user custom field to an ABAP Managed field. Some of these reasons could be that:

  • you want to change the case sensitivity flag of the domain of your key user custom field from case sensitive to not case sensitive
  • you want to have a specific conversion routine within the domain of your key user custom field 
  • you want to specify a certain DDIC search help or check table

Please note that this blog  exclusively addresses SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition and SAP S/4HANA On-Premise and doesn’t address SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, as the feature of ABAP Managed Fields is not available in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.

 

Convert a key user custom field to an ABAP Managed Field

Let’s assume you created, published and transported a key user custom field ZZ1_AssignedDepartment of type "Code List" of length 11 on the Sales Order business object (business context is SD_SALESDOC) where the code list consists out of three values (“Department1”, “Department2”, “Department3”).

Key user custom field creation for custom field ZZ1_AssignedDepartment

Several weeks after using the field in the production system, you may find that you want to change the code list values directly in the production system. This approach avoids maintaining these values in the development system and transporting them to the production system.

A more complicated approach to changing the code list values directly in the production system is to create a custom business object and use it in a new key user custom field of type “Association to Business Object”, since the data of custom business objects can be entered directly in the production system. You can transport the custom field along with all other development objects needed. As a next step, you create a report and class(es) in order to let you migrate the data from the old custom field to the new one.
The development effort for such a migration is significant, and it's even worse if you've already used the exposed old custom field in an integration scenario. You'd have to change everything there, too, as the name of the custom field changes.

Starting from S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2023 and On-Premise 2023, there is a new functionality that lets you convert the already existing key user custom field of type "Code List" to an ABAP Managed Field.
When you do this for a "Code List" field, the generated code value table, the code description table, the value help view, the value help description view, the data element, the domain, and the persistence include append all are preserved, but detached from the custom field itself. They're now under your manual control. This way, the code list values and descriptions are no longer part of the transport objects belonging to the custom field.
To be able to maintain the code values and code description values, there are multiple options:

  • create a maintenance view and maintenance dialog on top of the two persistence tables 
  • create a RAP application on top of these two persistence tables

In this blog, we'll show you the first option. Let's say you created a custom field ZZ1_AssignedDepartment. To convert this custom field to an ABAP Managed Field, and to make sure that the value help values can subsequently be maintained in the production system, follow this blog.

1. Open field ZZ1_AssignedDepartment in transaction SCFD_FIELDVIEWER

Open transaction SCFD_FIELDVIEWER in the system and client where you created the key user custom field ZZ1_AssignedDepartment. You'll see a list of all key user custom fields in that system. Double click the custom field ZZ1_AssignedDepartment.
When you go to the Enhancements tab on the field detail screen, you'll see the list of enhancements which have been generated for this particular key user custom field (see screenshot below). These enhancements all belong to this one custom field and can't be changed manually.

List of enhancements belonging to the custom field

2. Convert field ZZ1_AssignedDepartment to an ABAP Managed field

The next step is to click on the “Convert to ABAP Managed Field” button on the top left of the screen (see screenshot below). Make sure that the custom field you want to transform has been selected before on the left side of the screen.

Click on “Convert to ABAP Managed Fields” button

A popup will be shown asking you whether you “really want to convert the field to an ABAP managed field? The action is not reversible”. Click "Yes" to start the conversion process. As soon as the conversion has run, a respective success popup is shown.

Conversion success popup

Let's have a look at what happened behind the scenes during the conversion process:
Once again, have a look at the Enhancements tab of the custom field.

List of enhancements belonging to the custom field after the transformation

The list has become much shorter than before. The reason for that is that seven of the generated objects do now no longer exclusively belong to the custom field, but have been detached from the custom field and became independent development objects. These development objects are still used by the custom field, but can now be changed manually with the respective DDIC low-level tools, for example. These objects are:

      • Code Value Table: ZZ1_513D258A0759    
      • Code Description Table: ZZ1_EA4F9E9F7B2F     
      • CDS Code Value View: ZZ1_ASSIGNEDDEPARTMENT_V               
      • CDS Code Description View:  ZZ1_ASSIGNEDDEPARTMENT_W               
      • Data Element: ZZ1_ASSIGNEDDEPARTMENT               
      • Domain: ZZ1_ASSIGNEDDEPARTMENT
      • Persistence Include Append: ZZ1_VRTNU6KIWGDFIEIAVO2GXBFNTQ

With this transformation, the former custom field became an ABAP Managed Field as if it had been created from scratch as an ABAP Managed field using transaction SCFD_EUI. For this ABAP Managed Field, the same rules apply as for any other ABAP Managed field. The following two blogs dive deeper into ABAP Managed fields and address the specifics of them (especially regarding software logistics):

      • https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/convert-manually-created-append-fields-to-real-key-user-custom-fields/ba-p/13967399
      • https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/key-user-custom-fields-in-s-4hana-cloud-private-edition-and-on-premise-dos/ba-p/14026871

There is one more aspect to consider in case you want to transform a CodeList custom field to an AMF field. The code values and the code description values are no longer part of the transport object of the respective field. They do now only exist locally in the respective system and must be maintained in each system individually (but note: this is exactly what we wanted to achieve).

3. Create a maintenance view and a maintenance dialog for the code value and the code description table

The next step is to create a maintenance view for the code value table and the code description table. On top of this maintenance view, a maintenance dialog should be created. You can learn how to do this in the following blog: https://community.sap.com/t5/application-development-and-automation-blog-posts/getting-started-with-abap-how-to-create-maintenance-view/ba-p/13533494

Follow these steps to, for example, create the maintenance view ZZ1_DEPMNT_MV.

4. Maintain the code and the code description values using the maintenance view

Using the maintenance view ZZ1_DEPMNT_MV, you can now create, maintain, and delete entries for the two tables  ZZ1_513D258A0759 and ZZ1_EA4F9E9F7B2F. You can do this by navigating to the maintenance view using SE11. Click on Contents (see screenshot below).  The old values that you've maintained using the custom fields tool are preserved.

Maintain code values and code description locally using a maintenance view

Please note that the descriptions are maintained in table ZZ1_EA4F9E9F7B2F using the login language as language so you don't have to enter the language manually.

With this, you are done. You successfully transformed the key user custom field to an ABAP Managed Field. As a consequence, you no longer have to maintain the value help values (codes and descriptions) in the development system and transport them over to the target system. Now, you can maintain the values directly in the local system itself.

Please note that using a maintenance view in order to maintain the value help values (codes and descriptions) is just one possibility out of many. You could, for example, also create a RAP application on top of the code and description tables in order to create and maintain the value help values.

Now, you are done! Congratulations!
With this, you’re now equipped to convert a key user custom field to an ABAP Managed Field.

Please note that for the following field types of custom fields, a conversion to an ABAP Managed field is not supported:

  • “Amount with currency”
  • “Quantity with unit”
  • “Code List based on CDS View”
  • “Association to Business Object”

If you try to convert a field with this field type, you'll get an error popup telling you that the conversion for type [field type] is not supported.

Please note that this blog has been elaborated by a team of experts. I want to thank Yasmina van Rooij (YasminavanRooij), Karsten Schaser (Karsten_Schaser) and Christian Fuhlbruegge (ChristianFuhlbruegge) for their extremely helpful contributions.

Feedback, Comments, or Questions

You’re cordially invited to provide feedback, comments, or questions in the comments section below. Please follow our profiles to get updates when we publish more posts on these topics.
Feel invited to post and answer questions here (https://answers.sap.com/tags/270c4f37-c335-46e1-bfad-a256637d5e26) and read other posts on the topic (https://blogs.sap.com/tags/270c4f37-c335-46e1-bfad-a256637d5e26/).

Other related blog posts

  1. Convert Manually Created Append Fields to Real Key User Custom Fields 
  2. Key User Custom Fields in S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition and On-Premise: Dos and Don’ts
  3. How to implement a custom field of type “Code List based on CDS view” with a developer extensibility... 
    How to implement a custom entity in the ABAP RESTful Programming Model using remote function modules    
  4. SAP Screen Personas: How to position key user custom fields exactly where you want them to be

entry.title: On pressing create button of item table of object page in RAP it's being navigated to new blank page
entry.content:
Hello Team,

entry.title: Standard iFlow for consignments
entry.content:
Does SAP has a standard iFlow that we can use for consignments? We noticed that the Cart and Checkout Order Notifications standard iFlow only caters Orders and Delivery. 

 

 


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Standard iFlow for consignments
entry.content:
1. What is the standard iFlow for Consignments ?

    SAP provides standard integration content, including iFlows, for common scenarios. However, specific pre-packaged iFlows for consignment processes may not be provided as standard due to the diverse nature of consignment arrangements, which often require customization to fit specific business needs.As you have observed, the Cart and Checkout Order Notifications standard iFlow typically focuses on standard order and delivery processes rather than consignment-specific workflows. In consignment setups, additional considerations such as inventory ownership, stock levels, replenishment logic, and sales processing are required, which may not be covered by generic order and delivery iFlows.

    In this area we suggest to familiarize with OMSA integration for Commerce Cloud


  2. Why the standard iFlow for 'Replicate Cart and Checkout Order Notifications from ERP to SAP Commerce Cloud' is designed to use a single OData call for multiple operations—namely Order Creation, Order Cancellation, Goods Issue, and Delivery?

    It is an expected design pattern for SAP Commerce Cloud to be configured with a unified OData endpoint for these distinct business processes. This configuration is designed to streamline the integration process and ensure consistency across different operations. By using a single OData endpoint, the integration flow can efficiently handle multiple types of notifications without requiring separate endpoints for each action. This approach simplifies the integration architecture and reduces the complexity of managing multiple endpoints. It ensures that all related operations are handled through a unified interface, which can improve performance and maintainability.

    Refer to the following documentation for better understanding: Developing an OData API Project

  3. What the rationale is behind having a single iFlow to handle ORDERS05 and DELVRY07?

    The rationale for using a single iFlow to handle both ORDERS05 (Order Confirmation) and DELVRY07 (Delivery) is to streamline the integration process and ensure data consistency. By consolidating these operations into one iFlow, the flow of data between SAP Commerce Cloud and SAP S/4HANA or ERP can be managed more efficiently. This approach reduces complexity and ensures that both order creation and delivery processes are handled within a unified integration framework, simplifying maintenance and troubleshooting.

    If the business logic requires different handling for ORDERS05 and DELVRY07, splitting ORDERS05 and DELVRY07 into separate iFlows means creating distinct integration flows for each message type. This approach is typically used to handle different types of data or processes separately, ensuring that each iFlow is optimized for its specific purpose. For example, ORDERS05 might be used for handling order data, while DELVRY07 could be used for delivery data. If a split is required, it would involve customizing the standard iFlow, which will include cloning and configuring multiple independent iFlows.

  4. When is it required to update the EDMX in the OData Adapter ?

      In general, it is not required to manually update the EDMX in the OData Adapter when you are using post-exit to add custom fields, as the recommended approach is to extend the payload dynamically without directly changing the EDMX. It helps mitigate potential disruptions and simplifies future upgrades. So when the payload includes new fields and the adapter is strictly validating against EDMX, then you must update the EDMX


  5. It is known that custom fields can be added via post-exit but how they can be incorporated into the EDMX used by the OData Adapter for Commerce?

    To add custom fields in the EDMX used in the OData Adapter going to Commerce, you can follow these steps

    1. Create the Pre-Exit Integration Flow: This step involves mapping the extended source structure (Message A') to the original source structure (Message A). This allows the standard integration flow to consume the inbound message in the customer-specific scenario. For more details, refer to the Creating the Pre-Exit Integration Flow
    2.  Modify the EDMX File: You need to extend the EDMX file to include the custom fields. This involves editing the EDMX file to add the new fields to the entity types and properties.
    3. Update the OData Adapter Configuration: Configure the OData adapter to recognize the new fields. This includes updating the connection settings and ensuring that the adapter can handle the extended data structure.
    4. Deploy and Test: Deploy the updated integration flow and test it to ensure that the custom fields are correctly handled and propagated through the system.
    By following these steps, custom fields can be successfully added to the EDMX utilized by the OData Adapter, thereby ensuring that the integration flow is capable of handling the extended data structure.
    For detailed guidance please refer to Integration Flow Extension - Concepts


  6. If new custom fields are added to the message structure via post-exit, and corresponding fields exist on the Commerce side, it is to be expected that an error may occur. This is due to the fact that, within the standard iFlow, the OData Receiver adapter is not configurable, and therefore the 'Fields' parameter cannot be updated to include the custom fields?
        

           Yes, if you add new custom fields to the message structure via a post-exit iFlow and those fields are already present on the Commerce side, you are likely to encounter errors if you're still using the standard Replicate Cart or Checkout iFlow. The post-exit alone is not sufficient for handling structural changes in the standard iFlow. So if you're currently working with the standard iFlow, we recommend evaluating whether a custom version is needed to support the custom field requirements properly. That means creating a custom copy of the standard iFlow, where you can fully control the message mapping and OData call structure.

entry.title: Now Live in Canada: SAP Taulia Receivables Financing Embedded in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508
entry.content:
📢Introduction

We’re excited to announce that with the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 release, Taulia Receivables Financing is now officially available for Canadian customers! This embedded solution empowers businesses to unlock liquidity, improve working capital, and streamline financial operations—all from within their ERP.

💡What Is Embedded Receivables Financing?

Receivables financing allows businesses to convert outstanding invoices into immediate cash—without taking on traditional debt. With this new integration, the process is now fully embedded in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, eliminating the need for external platforms or manual uploads.

🌟Key Benefits

✅Hassle-Free Onboarding

Skip the lengthy bank setup. Activate financing directly within your ERP and start unlocking liquidity in days—not months.

💸Funding Within 24 Hours

Receive capital for eligible receivables in just one day, helping you manage cash flow and close the month with confidence.

🤖AI-Powered Pricing

Get instant, tailored pricing from a multifunder network using advanced AI models—at the click of a button.

🔄Touch-Free Reconciliation

Automated journal entries and payment records reduce manual effort and free up your finance team’s time.

🕵️‍♂️ Undisclosed Financing

Customers remain unaware of the receivables acceleration, preserving your business relationships.

🇨🇦Why This Matters for Canadian Businesses

With the 2508 release, Canadian companies using SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition can now:

  • Improve cash flow and reduce reliance on loans
  • Accelerate growth by reinvesting early capital
  • Optimize financial metrics by removing receivables from the balance sheet
  • Reduce credit risk, as financiers assume the risk of customer insolvency

🔁How It Works

  • Invoice Creation: Invoices are generated in S/4HANA Cloud
  • Selection & Sale: Choose which receivables to finance
  • Funding: Receivables are sold to Taulia or other financiers at a discount
  • Repayment: Customers pay either your business or directly to Taulia

📎Learn More

  • SAP Help Portal – Receivables Financing
  • Product tour

Authors: Aleksandr Baranov, Melissa Tonarelly

entry.title: Re: ePPDS resource cannot be deleted as only model-depend...
entry.content:
Hello Zoltan!

Have you tried to remove the resource from the model?

Follow these steps:
- Access transaction /N/SAPAPO/RES01
- Enter the resource you want to change (and only THIS information. Be careful NOT to fill out the planning version)
- Enter the resource information and click edit
- Select the resource
- In the top menu, select Model Assignments (it's a button with four dots)
- Select the associated model
- Select the "delete resource from the model" button

After deleting the model, you will be able to delete the resource from ePPDS normally and proceed with the correct creation of the MULTI resource.

If you have any problems or other questions, feel free to ask and I'll get back to you!

entry.title: Delete data from previous months after adding those to the targetmonth
entry.content:
Hello team,

I have a data action with the following code:

MEMBERSET [d/Date] = %SourceMonth% TO %TargetMonth%

MEMBERSET [d/CP_DI_Origem] = ("Compromissos")

DATA([d/Date] = %TargetMonth%) = RESULTLOOKUP([d/Date] = PREVIOUS(11, "MONTH", %TargetMonth%)) + RESULTLOOKUP([d/Date] = PREVIOUS(10, "MONTH", %TargetMonth%)) + RESULTLOOKUP([d/Date] = PREVIOUS(9, "MONTH", %TargetMonth%)) + RESULTLOOKUP([d/Date] = PREVIOUS(8, "MONTH", %TargetMonth%)) + RESULTLOOKUP([d/Date] = PREVIOUS(7, "MONTH", %TargetMonth%)) + RESULTLOOKUP([d/Date] = PREVIOUS(6, "MONTH", %TargetMonth%)) + RESULTLOOKUP([d/Date] = PREVIOUS(5, "MONTH", %TargetMonth%)) + RESULTLOOKUP([d/Date] = PREVIOUS(4, "MONTH", %TargetMonth%)) + RESULTLOOKUP([d/Date] = PREVIOUS(3, "MONTH", %TargetMonth%)) + RESULTLOOKUP([d/Date] = PREVIOUS(2, "MONTH", %TargetMonth%)) + RESULTLOOKUP([d/Date] = PREVIOUS(1, "MONTH", %TargetMonth%)) + RESULTLOOKUP([d/Date] = %TargetMonth%)

After calculating the sum for the target month, I want it to clear the values from the previous months.
Is there a way to do this in a single data action?

I tried using parameters, but I need to select multiple months from SourceMonth up to TargetMonth - 1. However, when using parameters, I'm only allowed to set granularity to single and cardinality to Leaf.

Can you help me with this?

Thank you very much,
Ganjos

entry.title: step by step guide for using Governance Rule to control transport in SAP Build
entry.content:
Now SAP Build allows users to create Governance Rules from templates, and use the predefined processes to control the creation and transport of their projects.

In this blog post we will look at how to implement it. We will start by setting up Cloud Transport Management Service (cTMS) to enable the transport between SAP Build Process Automation (SBPA) tenants, and then continue with adding governance rule in SAP Build to set an approval gateway before the content goes to Transport Management Service. 

 

The following articles are mainly referred to:

  • [SAP Help Portal] Configure Governance Rules https://help.sap.com/docs/build/sap-build-core/configure-governance-rules?locale=en-US
  • [SAP Help Portal] Documentation of the integration with SAP Cloud Transport Management: Transport a Project
  • [SAP Help Portal] SAP Content Agent Service https://help.sap.com/docs/content-agent-service/user-guide/create-target-node-destination
  • [SAP Blog] Transporting content in SAP BUILD Process Automation https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-members/transporting-content-in-sap-build-process-automation/bc-p/13556499
  • [SAP Blog] Configure Governance Rules in SAP Build https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/configure-governance-rules-in-sap-build/ba-p/14133093
  • [SAP Developers YouTube channel video] Set Up Rules for Who Can Create and Transport SAP Build Projects https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aLJTpAwYxyM&t=9s

Prerequisites:

  • You have a source SBPA tenant, and a target SBPA tenant (application subscription), and you have access to them and their Subaccounts.
  • You have subscription to cTMS tenant and you have access to it and its Subaccount.

Step 1: create service instances and their destinations

If you have not set up Transport for SBAP, you will need to start with creating several service instances and their destinations. If you are already able to transport contents from one SBPA tenant to another, then you can skip the first three steps and directly go to Step 4. 

This allow cTMS and SBPA to talk to each other via CAS. CAS is always free. 

The architecture will eventually look like: 

Step 1.1 create service instance and service key for cTMS

In the same Subaccount of cTMS subscription, create a service instance and service key, see Steps to use Transport Management using Programmatic Access (API Remote Call).

 

Step 1.2: create Content Agent Service (CAS) instances in source and target subaccounts

In the Subaccount of source and target SBPA, a CAS's service instance need to be created, choose Standard Plan and Assemble role for this plan in the creation wizard.  A service key need to be created. https://help.sap.com/docs/content-agent-service/user-guide/initial-setup

 

Step 1.3: create destinations for Content Agent Service (CAS) instances

And then, in the subaccount of cTMS, create transport destination Create Transport Destinations pointing to the CAS of source and target SAP BTP subaccounts.

 

Step 2: create a route with the source and target nodes

Step 2.1: create route in cTMS

With the source and target CAS created, you can now go to cTMS, create a route, with source and target nodes using the destinations that you created for the source and targeted CAS. For details about how to create nodes and routes, you can use route wizard to create one route and two nodes in one minute, details please check: 

  • create transport node Create Transport Nodes. Create transport nodes as representations of the source and target end points of deployment processes in your landscape. Add configuration details as required.
  • create transport route Create Transport Routes. In SAP Cloud Transport Management, transport routes are used to connect transport nodes.

 

Please note that the content type for process automation in SBPA is MTA, as listed here https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-transport-management/sap-cloud-transport-management/supported-content-types?locale=en-US 

example:

Step 2.2: create TransportManagementService destination 

And then, with the source node name, you can go to the source SBPA subaccount, and create a destination named TransportManagementService, pointing to the cTMS service instance, and specify the property to source node. This will allow you to perform Export from Content Agent UI, SAP Integration Suite UI, or SAP Build. Details see https://help.sap.com/docs/content-agent-service/user-guide/create-transportmanagementservice-destination

 

Step 2.3: add destination to SBPA source 

Now you can go to your source SBPA, in the control tower, you can add the TransportManagementService destination you created for cTMS service instance.

Step 3: Test the transport in SBPA

You can now test with the transport feature in SBPA.

Choose a project in SBPA, choose a release version, click the …, click Transport. 

In the source node, you need to choose the source node you created in the transport route in cTMS, and then give your description of the transport (if there are descriptions in your project, it will be automatically written). Then you can click Transport to start the process. 

The transport content will be packed as MTA to your cTMS source node, and you will see the tag “Transported” in your project release after success.

In your cTMS, you will see that your source node has transport event as succeeded. 

But in target node, you will need to first approve the transport request and then the content will be transported to your target SBPA. 

After succeeded, you can go to the target SBPA, and import the content as a project. First you will notice that there is a red notification icon displayed by import button, and then you click into it, you will find the available content. Choose it and click import, you will find it created as a project and you are the member of the project. 

This means that the transport of SBPA content via cTMS works.

Then you go to the second half of the post, to add the governance rule to transport.

Step 4: Create service instance, key, destination for source SBPA

Create a service instance and service key for source SAP Build Process Automation. See https://help.sap.com/docs/build/sap-build-core/configure-governance-rules?locale=en-US

Then create a destination pointing to the SBPA service instance you just created, using the authentication type of OAuth2UserTokenExchange. This is where a token representing one user (e.g., a JWT from XSUAA) is exchanged for another token for the same user but for a different audience or scope. This is crucial in multi-tier applications where a service needs to call another service, maintaining the original user's identity.

Remember to add a property to the destination: sap.processautomation.enabled=true.

Also add the destination to the source SBPA's control tower:

Step 5: enable the Governance Rule for Transport

In SBPA's control tower, Governance Rules, find the template to create the governance rule for transport.

When you click into the process of the newly created project, you will see the approval flow, and you can adjust it. By default, there is a questionnaire sent to the person who trigger the transport process, and then the filled out questionnaire will be sent for the same person (can be adjusted to your need) for approval.

You will need to release it, deploy it in the environment of Governance, and to the destination you just created for the source SBPA service instance:

And last but not least, you go back to the control tower, governance rule, and enable it for transport:

You can also do the same for project creation.

Step 5: Test it with transport

In lobby, find a project to transport. You will need to choose a released version of it, and in the transport dialog that opens, enter the description and choose the source node.

You will see that the status of the release turns into “complete transport questionnaire” (it will change according to which step you are in the transport governance rule process). The popout window reminds you of a pending questionnaire, and you can go to the questionnaire from here or in the My Inbox.

Next step is to complete the questionnaire:

And approve the questionnaire:

And then the content will be transport by CAS to the source node in cTMS, and the rest of the steps will be familiar to you.

Approve in target node:

Go to the target SBPA and you will find the content transported there:

In the source SPBA, you can check the past transport requests in control tower:

entry.title: News from SAP Activate SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 and more
entry.content:
We are pleased to announce the availability of the updates to SAP Activate and share exciting news – the launch of Joule in SAP Activate road map viewer – for customers, partners, and SAP internal users. We are also excited about the new visual design of the home page in the road map viewer and the updated user experience. This release introduces several exciting updates to the implementation guidance across a range of SAP Activate assets. We continue to aim to streamline and improve the implementation process, providing a more seamless experience for our valued users. Here are the key highlights for this release:

  • NEW - Enhance Your SAP Activate road map viewer Experience with Joule
  • Revamped Visual Design for the SAP Activate road map viewer
  • NEW - SAP Activate provisioning road map for SAP Business Suite packages
  • SAP Activate Community Blogs and Activate Minute Videos
  • Updates to SAP Activate for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
  • Updates to SAP Activate for SAP Cloud ERP Private Edition
  • Updates to SAP Activate for SAP Business Technology Platform
  • Updates to SAP Activate for Conversion of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2-system to 3-system landscape
  • Updates to SAP Activate for SAP SuccessFactors
  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Test Automation Tool 2508 Release

Enhance Your SAP Activate road map viewer Experience with Joule

We are thrilled to share that Joule is now generally available in the SAP Activate road map viewer. With Joule, customers, partners and SAP internal users can quickly ask Activate related questions and receive clear, helpful answers – making it easier to unlock the full value of SAP Activate.

Joule is available to all SAP for Me users and currently supports two of our most widely used road maps:

  • SAP Activate for SAP Cloud ERP Private – New Implementation
  • SAP Activate for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (3-system landscape)

To learn more about how to interact with Joule, check out the blog post here.

 

Revamped Visual Design for the SAP Activate road map viewer

We’ve enhanced the onboarding experience for new users of the SAP Activate road map viewer by introducing a fresh visual design, updated guidance, and built-in onboarding resources right on the home screen. Learn more about these improvements in this blog post. 

 

NEW SAP Activate provisioning road map for SAP Business Suite packages

We’re excited to announce the release of a dedicated SAP Activate provisioning road map for SAP Business Suite packages. This new resources is now available to customers in the road map viewer, and you can find more details in the blog post here.

 

SAP Activate Community | SAP Activate Blogs | SAP Activate Minute Videos

Join the SAP Activate Community to explore valuable content and resources while connecting with SAP partners, clients and internal colleagues by participating in discussions and sharing knowledge.

Make sure to follow the SAP Activate tag to access blog posts like those highlighted here, along with additional insights shared by SAP Activate experts within the community.

Recap of some blog posts from the community:

  • New Road Maps for SAP Business Network - Supplier Portal Private Edition and Commerce Automation by Ana Goetze
  • Key Enhancements to the SAP Fieldglass Road map by Ana Goetze
  • Learn Quickly via the SAP Activate Minute Videos by Dan Ciecko
  • Planning your System Conversion to SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition following SAP Activate by Jose Marquez Mares
  • Security, Data Protection and IAM guidelines in SAP Activate for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition by Kiran Bose
  • Accelerating Implementation with SAP Activate in the Public Cloud by user pranavgarud
  • Guiding Your Cloud Journey: The New SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition - Adoption Plan Roadmap by Christina Galbreath
  • Unlocking Innovation: Understanding SAP’s Clean Core and Its Benefits (for IT Leaders) by user arpin
  • Explore the SAP Activate Methodology using a reimagined Road Map Viewer by Ana Goetze
  • NEW SAP Activate provisioning road map for SAP Business Suite packages by Adnette Kamugisha

 

Updates of SAP Activate for SAP S/HANA Cloud Public Edition in 2508

The SAP Activate for SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud (3-system landscape) implementation roadmap has been enhanced based on product management input, system functionality changes, and customer feedback. Below are highlights for this release.

  • Introduced a new road map, SAP Activate for Cloud ERP, to guide customers through a cloud ERP implementation. This road map is the continuation of the Provisioning Enablement for SAP Cloud ERP road map and will be expanded to include all the products in the business suite packages.
  • Added road maps, SAP Business Network for Commerce Automation and SAP Ariba, to the combinable road map list in SAP Cloud ALM. This allows for better flexibility when implementing functionality related to the business suite packages.
  • Added a new deliverable, Introduction to SAP Business Suite, and three new tasks to the Discover phase to support learning about the SAP Business Suite along with the GROW with SAP and Rise with SAP journeys.
  • Added references to SAP WalkMe to increase visibility on how SAP WalkMe can help during the implementation.

 

Updates of SAP Activate for Cloud ERP Private Edition

The SAP Activate Methodology content for SAP Cloud ERP Private Edition continues to be enhanced to help guide the customer through the journey of a new implementation, system conversion, and selective data transition following the SAP Clean Core principles. These journeys are accessible by selecting the appropriate journey tag within the single roadmap in road map viewer or individually in SAP Cloud ALM.

Key highlights include:

  • In coordination with the Regional Implementation Group (RIG), several updates have been made in the roadmaps for SAP Activate for SAP Cloud ERP Private - New Implementation. 
  • The Discover phase has been updated with a new deliverable Introduction to SAP Business Suite Discover Phase and three new tasks Understand your SAP Cloud Journey, Review the SAP Business Suite Offering and Try SAP. These new tasks aligned with the new Business Suite messaging and content on the sap.com. 
  • All the transition scenarios now include WalkMe Premium guidance and project implementation can leverage the WalkMe as a digitial adoption platform to help enhance user onboarding and enablement throughout their transformation journey. Learn more by reviewing the WalkMe product tag.   
  • During System Conversion customers can leverage the RISE with SAP System Transition Workbench, a tool that offers a single, highly automated, guided system transition processes that integrates all essential technical activities and tools. Learn more by reviewing the SAP Blog - Introducing the RISE with SAP System Transition Workbench.
  • Several updates made to the Data Management workstream, with updated tasks, description, procedure steps and updated accelerators. 
  • In the past few releases, we made updates to the Project Management workstream. The updates include enhanced description of key deliverables, tasks and accelerators and improve workflow efficiency and ensure consistency across project lifecycle. 

 See the release notes for a complete list of all improvements.

 

Updates of SAP Activate for SAP Business Technology Platform

We’re excited to announce the release of new content designed to support customers in the following topics:

  • Implementation of SAP Integration Suite capabilities - It offers a structured approach that leverages best practices, tools, and methodologies to support end-to-end integration project lifecycles — from discovery and planning to implementation and go-live.
  • New content to help assist customers with the migration from SAP Process Orchestration (SAP PO) to the modern, cloud-based SAP Integration Suite and covering the following aspects of the migration project
    • A phased migration approach tailored to your landscape
    • Best practices for analyzing and refactoring integration content
    • Tooling support and checklists for assessment and execution
  • End-to-end implementation guidance for SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP) application development capabilities. This content supports teams in identifying business cases, selecting the right cloud development models, and successfully designing, building, and deploying applications using SAP BTP.

 

Updates of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2-system landscape to 3-system landscape 

We are excited to share the latest improvements to the SAP Activate guidance for our SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition customers converting from a 2-system landscape to a 3-system landscape. Since the last major release in January, we have made several updates to the guidance based on our learnings from conversion projects. The key updates are outlined below:

  • Added guidance for the use of the Parallel Line capability after the conversion to the 3-system landscape. This includes the self-enablement tasks in the Prepare and Run phases as well as a new task redirecting to the Parallel Line content in SAP Activate for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, 3-system landscape. (link)
  • Added new task Request Activation of Scope Item 5XU to Use SAP Document and Reporting Compliance into the Prepare phase to trigger the activation checks earlier in the conversion process. (link)
  • Updated task Activate Scope Item 5XU to Use SAP Document and Reporting Compliance in the Realize phase. (link)
  • Added new task, Validate IT contact prior to contract signature, to the Discover phase to ensure the IT contact is available during the conversion weekend. (link)
  • Updated task Create SAP for Me case to allow SAP proactively check your environment to indicate that part of the procedure is only intended for Solution Builder based cases. (link)
  • Added new task, Fix the affected workflows to the Realize phase with instructions on how to fix and re-transport the workflows. Including new accelerator Help - Flexible Workflow - Agent Rules that is added to the task (link)
  • Added a new task, Copy Missing Business Roles from Production System to Test System, to the deliverable Initial System Access After Conversion, to copy business roles from the production tenant to the test tenant when they are missing.

We recommend that you review the detailed release notes in the SAP Activate road map viewer for the latest content updates and view the conversion overview video here. Additionally, bookmark the SAP Community page dedicated to conversion topics here.

 

Updates of SAP Activate for SAP SuccessFactors

The SAP Activate for SAP SuccessFactors roadmap has been enhanced based on product management input, system functionality changes, and customer feedback. Below are the highlights:

  • Updated phase/workstream graphic to reflect the current deliverable structure in the road map.
  • Expanded the Baseline Activation Service for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition and SAP SuccessFactors road map by adding SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central.
  • Updated the several tasks in the Project Management workstream to be consistent and combinable with other road maps.
  • Added references to SAP WalkMe to increase visibility on how SAP WalkMe can help during the implementation.

 

SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Test Automation Tool 2508 Release

The 2508 release introduces significant enhancements to the Test Automation Tool (TAT) for SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition, with a focus on improved usability and intelligent navigation. Key highlights include:

  • Enhanced Post Upgrade Tests Dashboard
    • Advanced Filtering: Easily filter results by Test Plan, Release, Process Type, Status and Application Area
    • Focused Analysis: Reduce information overload and quickly access relevant data
    • Faster Decision-Making: Improved data visualization for faster analysis
  • Joule Navigation Integration
    • Universal Access: Joule navigation is now available across all TAT applications
    • Seamless Movement: Deep links enable effortless movement between test automation modules
    • Prompt-Based Access: Quickly open any TAT app using intuitive prompts

These enhancements greatly boost testing efficiency, minimize manual navigation, and increase user productivity throughout all test automation workflows.

For more details, refer to the blog on the 2508 features in the Test Automation Tool.

 

Run simple – SAP Activate – Accelerate and simplify the adoption of SAP S/4HANA Cloud.

entry.title: Re: Issue with mbt build in Newly Created CAP Project on...
entry.content:
Hi BhanuKiran1,

Have you resolved the issue? I had the same issue, with error: the "gen/db" path of the "mycapman-db-deployer" module does not exist

And then I found the cause: it is because I update the CDS version. In older cds version, the build and deployment command becomes  will generate gen/db folder, and put HANA HDI artifacts there. If you like me update cds-dk to CAP v7.x or higher (currently there is v9), then the cds build will not generate gen/db folder, because cds deploy can directly take care of the database creation or deployment.

I found in the output of my `cds build --production` command, the build task only has srv for nodejs, and has no db related task:

INFO executing the "npx cds build --production" command...
building project with {
  versions: { cds: '9.1.0', compiler: '6.1.0', dk: '9.1.0' },
  target: 'gen',
  tasks: [
    { src: 'srv', for: 'nodejs', options: { model: [ 'db', 'srv', 'app', '@sap/cds/srv/outbox' ] } }
  ]
}

 

Solution could be,

(1) as workaround you can add this after current build command: `cds build --src db --for hana --no-clean`(this can be found in your package.json, scripts section);

or (2) as recommended by the document, you add to the cds.require production build profile db as kind: hana (this can be found in the package.json or .cdsrc.json or .cdsrc-private.json file, for instance:

"[production]": {
        "db": {
          "kind": "hana",
          "credentials": {
            "url": ":memory:"
          }
        },

In your case, it could be adding parameter for PostgreSQL. After the change the hana db task is run and gen/db is generated, as shown in output:

{
build: {
target: 'gen',
tasks: [
{ for: 'hana', src: 'db', options: { model: ['db', 'srv', 'app'] }},
{ for: 'nodejs', src: 'srv', options: { model: ['db', 'srv', 'app'] }}
]
}
}
done > wrote output to:
gen/db/...

You can refer to this document https://cap.cloud.sap/docs/guides/deployment/custom-builds

entry.title: Re: Purchase order
entry.content:
Hello @MM1234 ,

Use a use custom negative condition type in PO.

You can model the Rs. 300/MT incoming incentive using a negative value condition type at the PO item level.

Steps:
1. Create a Custom Condition Type (if not already available)
Go to SPRO → Materials Management → Purchasing → Conditions → Define Price Determination Process
Copy an existing condition type (e.g., ZRET) and create a new one:
Name: ZINC (Incentive)
Category: Discount or surcharge
Calculation Type: Per unit
Condition Class: A (Price)
Allow negative values

2. Assign It to the Pricing Schema
Include ZINC in your pricing procedure (e.g., RM0000 if standard)
Place it after the net price or freight conditions
Mark it as statistical if it’s just informational, or non-statistical if it should post to accounting

3. Maintain the Condition in the PO
In the Purchase Order:
Material Price: 0 (tick “Free” checkbox)
Add condition ZINC with value -300 per MT

4. Check FI Impact
If ZINC is non-statistical, it will:
Create a credit posting to a G/L account (vendor rebate/incentive revenue). You need to assign the correct account key and G/L account in OBYC or MM pricing schema

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos. This motivates me to serve you better.
Appreciate your feedback.
Thanks,
Divyesh
